IMHO anyone deploying druid needs appropriate production monitoring for performance. I suggest the goal here to be to catch obvious performance degradations, and not attempt to catch things that are completely scale dependent (ex: if something runs fine on a 4 core instance, but not on a 32 core instance, I don't think these tests are the appropriate place to catch such a thing)

The type of testing machine determines the repeatability of the tests, and as such, a VM or laptop would have to simply have more tests run to have a high degree of confidence in performance results. Such a scenario (assuming the VM is reasonable, like not a T-series from AWS) then I would expect it to be able to catch major performance regressions.

I think the setup should be able to maintain history and fail tests only when there is a performance regression, depending on the hardware, absolute time taken to run a test might be high or low but on same hardware the time should not vary too much.

@drcrallen, thanks for the information, currently i can not open the video from my network in china...

@drcrallen @binlijin what I had said in the dev sync was that I think it does make sense to rename the thread. it tells you what query is running in that thread, which is helpful when looking at thread dumps or jconsole.

IMO the best way to do this is something like what SpecificSegmentQueryRunner does: rename the thread inside a try/finally where the "finally" changes the name back to the original name. And for the thread name, IMO a nice one is:

```
String.format("%s[%s_%s_%s]", currentThreadName, queryType, dataSource, queryId)
```

So that would give thread names like,

```
qtp1706655559-42[topN_mydatasource_queryUUID]
```
@gianm, it is a very good idea.
I will resolve conflicts if it has another +1 besides mine.

@fjy doc reorganized. Is it ok?

As a general update here, the extension is functioning fine so far internally. With the upgrades for 0.9.0 I have removed the requirement to have a big fat jar, instead allowing for spark to be specified loaded only in the local classpath as part of the hadoop coordinates.
Memory is still an issue, but I _think_ some of the memory improvements in 0.9.0 should make that less of a concern. Testing is underway internally for verification of this.
minor comments, but overall :+1:

@navis I am just wondering whether we could introduce a flag that prevents the result sequence materialized in the output or other ways to do the similar things. IMHO, this is beacuse the client would be expected to get the result from the given forwardURL, not from the HTTP response and it takes a long time to produce such a large number of rows, which is not used.
@CHOIJAEHONG1 current implementation returns empty sequence when `forwardURL != null`.
